Stem: Choose the correct word for the definition: What the atmosphere is like at a certain place and time.
Choices: A) weather, B) climate, C) weather hazard, D) season
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure vocabulary definition recall.
DCI Justification: Tests vocabulary definition. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Provide weather data for a specific day and climate data for a region and ask students to distinguish between them.

Stem: Complete the sentence: Climate is the —
Choices: A) weather you see outside right now, B) rain or snow outside, C) winter weather, D) average daily weather over an extended period at a particular location
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure vocabulary definition recall.
DCI Justification: Tests vocabulary definition. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Combine with Q1 into a single data-driven question comparing weather data and climate data.

Stem: Complete the sentence: Different organisms vary in how they look and function because they have —
Choices: A) feelings, B) styles, C) inherited traits, D) none of these
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Sentence completion. Pure recall.
DCI Justification: Tests basic vocabulary. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Provide family trait data and ask students to identify the reason for variation using evidence.

Stem: Complete the sentence: An example of an acquired trait is —
Choices: A) a scar, B) fur pattern, C) flower color, D) how much water a plant needs, E) ability to see
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Classification recall.
DCI Justification: Tests basic understanding of acquired vs. inherited traits.
Key Recommendation: 5-option MC format is non-standard. Provide data on traits across generations and ask students to classify.

Stem: Complete the sentence: An example of an inherited trait is —
Choices: A) a broken leg, B) learning to juggle, C) being good at swimming, D) eye color
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Classification recall.
DCI Justification: Tests basic understanding of inherited traits.
Key Recommendation: Provide family trait data across generations and ask students to identify inherited patterns.

Stem: Which of the following DOES NOT show an example of how living in a group benefits some animals?
Choices: A) It gives them protection, B) They share responsibility of raising young, C) They have social structures that help survive, D) They attract more predators
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Identifying the non-example from a list.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of group behavior benefits. Basic application.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on survival rates for grouped vs. solitary animals and ask students to analyze.

Stem: If you drop an object off a roof and it falls downward, this is because of —
Choices: A) the Earth's gravitational pull, B) static electricity, C) balanced forces, D) magnetic energy
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall of gravity concept.
DCI Justification: Tests basic knowledge of gravity. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Provide data from drop experiments at different heights and ask students to identify the force causing the pattern.

Stem: What causes an object to move?
Choices: A) unbalanced forces, B) balanced forces, C) contact forces, D) no force
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall.
DCI Justification: Tests basic force concept. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Provide force data from experiments and ask students to identify when objects moved vs. stayed still.

Stem: What causes hair to stand up when you rub a balloon on it?
Choices: A) a magnetic field, B) gravity, C) static electricity, D) friction
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall of static electricity.
DCI Justification: Tests basic knowledge of static electricity. Recall level.
Key Recommendation: Provide data from rubbing different materials together and their effects. Ask students to identify the pattern.

Stem: If each girl is pulling using the same force, is there likely to be movement and in which direction?
Image/Diagram Description: Image showing two girls pulling rope from opposite sides (508x248).
Choices: A) No because forces are balanced, B) No because forces are unbalanced, C) Yes and it will move to the right, D) Yes and it will move to the left
Scenario Justification: Simple visual scenario with two girls in tug-of-war.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Force balance identification.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of balanced forces. Basic application with visual.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (equal forces → no movement).
Key Recommendation: Note: Answer key says C but context suggests A (balanced forces). Provide force magnitude data and ask students to predict outcomes.

Stem: How would you describe the temperature in an arctic climate compared to a tropical climate based on these graphs?
Image/Diagram Description: Two climate graphs comparing Nuuk Greenland (arctic) and Nosy Be Madagascar (tropical) (674x500 and 660x487).
Choices: A) Arctic temperatures same as tropical, B) Arctic temperatures much higher than tropical, C) No way to compare with just graphs, D) Arctic temperatures much lower than tropical
Scenario Justification: Real climate data graphs for two contrasting locations. Students must compare and interpret graphical data.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — students compare two climate graphs to draw conclusions about temperature differences.
DCI Justification: Requires interpreting real climate data from graphs and comparing across locations.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (temperature patterns differ between climate zones).
Key Recommendation: Excellent data-driven comparison question. Students interpret and compare real climate graphs.

Stem: Gary sees a blizzard warning. Which will NOT help stay safe during a blizzard?
Choices: A) first aid kit, B) fan, C) food, D) blankets
Scenario Justification: Brief real-world scenario about blizzard preparation.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of weather hazard preparedness. Basic application.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on blizzard survival strategies and outcomes and ask students to evaluate which are most effective.

Stem: Which animal demonstrates a trait that helps it survive and hide from predators?
Image/Diagram Description: Four animal images showing different camouflage situations.
Choices: A) [Animal A], B) [Animal B], C) [Camouflaged animal C], D) [Animal D]
Scenario Justification: Visual scenario with animal images. Students identify camouflage.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — comparing visual evidence of camouflage across four animals.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of camouflage as a survival adaptation.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (coloring → blending in → survival).
Key Recommendation: Good visual comparison. Elevate by providing data on predation rates for camouflaged vs. non-camouflaged animals.

Stem: How is the life cycle of a duck different than the life cycle of a lion?
Choices: A) Lions hatch from eggs and ducks do not, B) Lions have adult phase and ducks do not, C) Ducks have adult phase and lions do not, D) Baby ducks hatch from eggs and lions do not
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure comparison recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of different reproductive strategies.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns implicitly (hatching vs. live birth).
Key Recommendation: Provide life cycle data for multiple animals and ask students to compare and identify patterns.

Stem: Monarch butterflies fly south when daylight decreases as winter approaches. This is an example of an organism —
Choices: A) migrating, B) germinating, C) escaping predators, D) recycling nutrients
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario about monarch behavior. Classification task.
DCI Justification: Tests knowledge of migration as a behavior. Recall level.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on monarch migration routes and survival rates and ask students to explain the advantage.

Stem: A turtle will be best camouflaged when it —
Choices: A) swims quickly in the water, B) blends in with its environment, C) sits in the sunlight, D) eats both plants and animals
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall of camouflage concept.
DCI Justification: Tests basic understanding of camouflage.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on turtle survival rates in different environments and ask students to identify the pattern.

Stem: Weather data table for Rochester NY in June. What is the predicted highest air temperature for June 29?
Image/Diagram Description: Data table showing predicted weather for 3 days in Rochester (644x327).
Scenario Justification: Real weather data table. Students must read and interpret data.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — reading a data table to find specific information.
DCI Justification: Tests ability to read and interpret weather data tables.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (reading data patterns from a table).
Key Recommendation: Data is present but task is simple data lookup. Elevate by asking students to compare data and make predictions.

Stem: Which diagram has the stages of plant development labeled correctly?
Image/Diagram Description: Four diagrams of plant development stages with labels.
Choices: A) [Diagram A], B) [Diagram B], C) [Diagram C], D) [Correctly labeled diagram D]
Scenario Justification: Visual diagrams of plant stages. Students identify correct labeling.
DCI Justification: Tests knowledge of plant development stages. Application with visuals.
Key Recommendation: Provide plant growth data over time and ask students to match stages to evidence.

Stem: The diagram shows the development of a butterfly. This sequence of changes is called —
Choices: A) hibernation, B) migration, C) a life span, D) a life cycle
Scenario Justification: Visual diagram but task is vocabulary identification.
DCI Justification: Tests vocabulary. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Provide unfamiliar organism development data and ask students to identify if it follows a life cycle pattern.

Stem: Students placed two sets of identical magnets near each other. After diagram shows one set attracted and one did not. Which statement best explains?
Image/Diagram Description: Before and after diagrams showing two sets of magnets with different outcomes (343x471).
Choices: A) First set moved together because opposite poles attracted, B) Second set didn't move because distance was too large, C) First set moved because north pole was stronger than south, D) Second set didn't move because they need electricity
Scenario Justification: Experimental scenario with visual data (before/after) showing two different magnet outcomes.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations from Evidence' — using visual evidence to explain different outcomes for two magnet configurations.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of magnetic pole interactions and attraction.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (opposite poles → attraction, same poles → no attraction).
Key Recommendation: Good visual comparison scenario. Elevate by adding data from multiple magnet configurations.

Stem: Dolphins live in pods. Which two activities are easier because they live in a pod?
Choices: A) communicating with different species, B) swimming in calm waters, C) breathing above surface, D) hunting for prey, E) finding a mate
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario about dolphin group behavior. Multi-select.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — reasoning about which activities benefit from group living.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of group behavior benefits. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (group living → easier hunting and mating).
Key Recommendation: Multi-select adds complexity. Provide data on pod vs. solo dolphin hunting success rates.

Stem: Blackbirds eat small seeds with hard shells. Which part of the bird helps it crack open the seed?
Choices: A) eyes, B) beak, C) feathers, D) wing
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario with visual but task is simple identification.
DCI Justification: Tests basic structure-function relationship. Recall level.
Key Recommendation: Provide beak shape data for multiple bird species and their diets and ask students to identify the pattern.

Stem: A student makes a box with a hidden magnet. Paper clip on a string moves toward a specific position. Which number shows where the magnet is hidden?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing box with numbered positions and paper clip on string (335x425).
Scenario Justification: Interesting spatial reasoning scenario. Students use evidence of magnetic attraction direction to locate hidden magnet.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations from Evidence' — using the paper clip's movement direction to infer magnet location.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of magnetic attraction and spatial reasoning.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (magnet position → paper clip direction).
Key Recommendation: Good reasoning-from-evidence question. Elevate by providing multiple paper clip positions and asking students to triangulate.

Stem: What is a fossil?
Choices: A) A living example of a plant or animal, B) Preserved parts or traces of animals or plants that lived in the past, C) A type of underwater shell, D) Rocks and minerals that can be combined
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure definition recall.
DCI Justification: Tests vocabulary definition. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Provide fossil images and ask students to compare them with modern organisms to draw conclusions.

Stem: Which statement is something fossils CANNOT tell us about a plant or animal?
Choices: A) What the organisms liked or disliked, B) How organisms have changed over time, C) What an organism looked like, D) When the organism lived on Earth
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Understanding limitations of fossil evidence.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall with reasoning.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of what fossils can and cannot reveal. Application level.
Key Recommendation: Provide actual fossil evidence and ask students to identify what can and cannot be determined.

Stem: What are the dangers of a blizzard?
Choices: A) It might ruin a picnic, B) It can cause cold weather injuries and make travel dangerous, C) It can make people too hot, D) It can cause sunburn
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall. Identical to G3.4 Q28.
DCI Justification: Tests basic knowledge of blizzard dangers. Pure recall.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on blizzard impacts and ask students to analyze patterns and design safety solutions.

Stem: Mouse species with light and dark fur on different colored ground. Hawks move in. Which diagram shows how population most likely changed?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing mice on different colored ground (324x192); four answer diagrams showing population changes.
Choices: A) [Population change A], B) [Population change B], C) [Population change C], D) [Mice matched to ground color survive]
Scenario Justification: Rich scenario with visual data showing predator-prey interaction and natural selection of camouflage. Multi-step reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations from Evidence' — students must reason about which mice survive based on camouflage advantage and predict population change.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding of how camouflage provides survival advantage against predators and predicting population outcomes.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (camouflage → survival → population change) and Patterns.
Key Recommendation: Excellent question approaching Doing Science level. Students predict population changes based on camouflage and predation.

Stem: Brad and Brian must separate a mixture. Which items can they remove with a magnet and why?
Choices: A) Iron filings and paperclips because they are magnetic, B) Toothpicks iron filings and notebook paper because all magnetic, C) Broken crayons notebook paper and sand because all magnetic, D) Broken crayons and chocolate chips because they are magnetic
Scenario Justification: Brief engineering-type scenario about separating a mixture.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — using magnetic properties to solve a separation problem.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of which materials are magnetic. Application level.
Key Recommendation: Provide data from testing multiple materials and ask students to classify and explain which are magnetic.

Stem: After a flower is pollinated, it can make seeds and fruit. What can pollinate flowers? Select two.
Choices: A) energy from sunlight, B) wind and water, C) birds and insects, D) nutrients from the soil
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Classification recall. Multi-select.
DCI Justification: Tests knowledge of pollination agents. Recall level.
Key Recommendation: Multi-select format. Provide pollination experiment data and ask students to identify effective agents.

Stem: Two magnets of same size at different distances from iron filings. Which will pick up more?
Choices: A) Magnet X because magnetic force is stronger when closer, B) Magnet Y because force gets stronger with distance, C) Neither because magnets don't attract iron filings, D) Both will pick up same because same size
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario comparing magnet distances.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Recall of distance-force relationship.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that magnetic force decreases with distance.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (closer distance → stronger force → more filings).
Key Recommendation: Provide data table from magnet-distance experiment and ask students to identify the pattern.

Stem: Which of the following is an example of an inherited trait?
Choices: A) Maya's ability to play piano after lessons, B) Jackson's blue eyes like his mother's, C) Carlos's knowledge of a second language, D) Aisha's long hair because she never cuts it
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Classification recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of inherited vs. acquired traits.
Key Recommendation: Provide family trait data and ask students to classify with evidence.
